user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_thread_:
```c
int
MHD_create_thread_ (MHD_thread_handle_ID_ *handle_id,
                    size_t stack_size,
                    MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_ start_routine,
                    void *arg)
{
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS)
  int res;
#if defined(MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_)
  pthread_t *const new_tid_ptr =
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ (handle_id);
#else  /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ */
  pthread_t new_tid;
  pthread_t *const new_tid_ptr = &new_tid;
#endif /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_ */

  mhd_assert (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (*handle_id));

  if (0 != stack_size)
  {
    pthread_attr_t attr;
    res = pthread_attr_init (&attr);
    if (0 == res)
    {
      res = pthread_attr_setstacksize (&attr,
                                       stack_size);
      if (0 == res)
        res = pthread_create (new_tid_ptr,
                              &attr,
                              start_routine,
                              arg);
      pthread_attr_destroy (&attr);
    }
  }
  else
    res = pthread_create (new_tid_ptr,
                          NULL,
                          start_routine,
                          arg);

  if (0 != res)
  {
    errno = res;
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_invalid_ (handle_id);
  }
#if ! defined(MHD_thread_handle_ID_get_native_handle_ptr_)
  else
    MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_ (handle_id, new_tid);
#endif /* ! MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_current_thread_ID_ */

  return ! res;
#elif defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  uintptr_t thr_handle;
#if SIZEOF_SIZE_T != SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_INT

  mhd_assert (! MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_ (*handle_id));

  if (stack_size > UINT_MAX)
  {
    errno = EINVAL;
    return 0;
  }
#endif /* SIZEOF_SIZE_T != SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_INT */
  thr_handle = (uintptr_t) _beginthreadex (NULL,
                                           (unsigned int) stack_size,
                                           start_routine,
                                           arg,
                                           0,
                                           NULL);
  if ((MHD_thread_handle_native_) 0 == (MHD_thread_handle_native_) thr_handle)
    return 0;

  MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_ (handle_id, \
                                           (MHD_thread_handle_native_) \
                                           thr_handle);

  return ! 0;
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_create_thread_:
#define MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_(hndl_id) MHD_thread_handle_is_valid_((hndl_id).handle)
...
#define MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_invalid_(hndl_id_ptr) (MHD_thread_handle_set_invalid_(&((hndl_id_ptr)->handle)),MHD_thread_ID_set_invalid_(&((hndl_id_ptr)->ID)))
...
#define MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_native_handle_(hndl_id_ptr, native_val) MHD_thread_handle_set_native_(&((hndl_id_ptr)->handle),native_val)
...
typedef struct _MHD_thread_handle_ID_ MHD_thread_handle_ID_
...
typedef pthread_t MHD_thread_handle_native_
...
typedef MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_
(MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_ *MHD_THREAD_START_ROUTINE_)(void *cls)
...
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS 1
...
#define SIZEOF_SIZE_T 8
...
#define SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_INT 4
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I did not flag other fragments because they use only standard C language constructs, the C preprocessor, or platform API/library calls (POSIX pthreads, Windows _beginthreadex) rather than compiler language extensions. There are no explicit uses of known compiler-extension keywords or constructs such as __attribute__, __declspec, typeof, asm, GCC statement-expressions ({ ... }), anonymous structures/unions that are nonstandard, or inline assembly. The backslash-newline sequences are ordinary preprocessor line splicing (standard), casts and the comma operator in macros are standard C, and typedefs like pthread_t and uintptr_t are standard library types. The only locations that may hide compiler-specific language extensions are the calling-convention/return-type macros used in the thread-start typedef and the use of that typedef in the function parameter; those macros (MHD_THRD_CALL_SPEC_, MHD_THRD_RTRN_TYPE_) could expand to compiler-specific calling conventions or attributes (for example __stdcall, __cdecl, or compiler attributes) and therefore should be investigated. No other code fragments in the provided code exhibit clear use of documented compiler language extensions.
